dublin_core.dcvalue: Association between smartphone use and head down tilt posture has not yet been quantitatively evaluated in natural settings This study aimed to objectively assess the angle and duration of head down tilt posture of smartphone users during a typical working day via naturalistic data collection Thirty one college students conducted their typical school activities while their head posture and smartphone app usage records were collected simultaneously for 8 hours Participants spent 125 9 minutes median usage duration on their smartphones with significantly larger head down tilt p Under 0 05 than when they were not using the phone Head tilt angle greater than 30 was found to be more common when using the phone while head tilt less than 20 was more common when they were not using the phone Study findings provide empirical evidence that supports an association between the duration of smartphone use and the intensity of head down tilt posture
Naturalistic data collection of head posture during smartphone use.
